description: Attested since the 1610s, from the earlier form trouzes (attested since the 1580s), extended from trouse (1570s), with plural ending typical of things in pairs, from Middle Irish triubhas (“close-fitting shorts”), of uncertain origin. The unexplained intrusive second -r- is perhaps due to the influence of drawers.

entries.meaning: An article of clothing that covers the part of the body between the waist and the ankles or knees, and is divided into a separate part for each leg.
examples: Synonyms: breeches, britches, (all Britain, dialectal) kecks, (chiefly US) pants, (Australia) strides; see also Thesaurus:trousers
The trousers need to be shortened.
Why can women wear trousers when men can’t wear skirts?
